refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: Lighting in scilab aproximates real world lighting where the appearence of a surface is given by interactions between light rays and the material properties of the surface. Because simulate real world lighting is complex and computationaly expesive, one uses a simplified model.
A light is represented mainly by its colors: ambient, diffuse and specular. It can be created using light_create function, and deleted using light_delete function.

The surface material properties is represented also by its colors (ambient, diffuse and specular) and it shininess level. The surface contains the color_material property that enables the use of the surface color as the diffuse color.
The final surface color is given by the product of the light and surface color.

listitem.para: Ambient color models the light received indirect by the surface and is independent of the surface normal or light direction.
Diffuse color models the light received directly, and thus it's dependent of the light ray direction and the surface normal.
Specular color defines the specular highlight color.

listitem.para: This field defines if the light is enabled "on" or disabled "off".

This field defines the type of light used. There are two types avaiable:"directional" and "point". Directional lights are positioned infinitely far from the surface thus emitting parallel rays. Point lights are defined as a point in space thus emitting rays in all directions.
This field defines the ray direction for directional light. The direction can be chaged using a 3 element vector "[x, y, z]" representing a vector starting from the origin.
This field defines the light position for point light. The position can be changed using a 3 element vector "[x, y, z]".
This field defines the ambient color of the light. The color is defined by a 3 element vector "[red, green, blue]" with each element in the range [0, 1].
This field defines the diffuse color of the light. The color is defined by a 3 element vector "[red, green, blue]" with each element in the range [0, 1].
This field defines the specular color of the light. The color is defined by a 3 element vector "[red, green, blue]" with each element in the range [0, 1].
This field is use to enable the use of the surface color as diffuse color. Its default value is "on".
This field defines the shininess level of the surface.
This field defines the ambient color of the surface. The color is defined by a 3 element vector "[red, green, blue]" with each element in the range [0, 1].

This field defines the diffuse color of the surface. The color is defined by a 3 element vector "[red, green, blue]" with each element in the range [0, 1]. Notice that this field is only used when color_material is disabled.
This field defines the specular color of the surface. The color is defined by a 3 element vector "[red, green, blue]" with each element in the range [0, 1].
